body: How can this be implemented within the estimators? Numba requires tags/decorators at each function to be compiled.

For example, how would you implement a soft dependency for this method:

```python
@njit(
    "float32[:](float32[:,:],int32[:],int32[:],float32[:],optional(int32))",
    fastmath=True,
    parallel=False,
    cache=True,
)
def _fit_biases(X, dilations, num_features_per_dilation, quantiles, seed):
   ...
```
I think this would have a large impact on the classification and clustering packages. There are probably 20+ files in sktime so far which use it.
also used in the distances, transformations and regression package. I do not see the benefit
it's mostly localized, and minimizing soft dependencies is of general benefit
Adds a large amount of boilerplate code, I'm against this

The reason for the large amount of boilerplate code is that many of the distances and utility functions are lying around loosely and not part of any class. Were they part of an object, we could deal with this via a tag or import-on-contsruction.

> I think we should turn `numba` into a soft dependency, since it is not core to the framework, but used only in specific estimators.
> 
> Any thoughts?

This would be very helpful. This is one of the reasons why we are unable to upgrade to the latest version of `sktime` since `numba` has some problems in our environment. If it could be made optional, it would be awesome!

Ref: https://github.com/numba/numba/issues/4908
cc: @hancelpv
Do you have any more information about this installation issue @ngupta23? i.e. the Python and numba versions. Whether numba is made a soft dependency or not, it is still an issue to resolve.
Agreed. you would not be able to use around 50% (?) of all time series classification, regression, transformation packages without numba being installed.

As an additional point, I think we should be using numba as often as possible (where appropriate) for our estimators. It offers significant performance gains when used correctly at almost no detriment to user or developer. 

By making it a soft dependency we're implying it's a niche utility. It shouldn't be perceived this way but instead as one of sktimes developers best ways to optimise their code.

> Agreed. you would not be able to use around 50% (?) of all time series classification, regression, transformation packages without numba being installed.

Well, some users are not able to use 100% of all time series classification, regression, and transformation estimators because numba is installed, see above @ngupta23's comment.

We should strive to minimize dependencies and make optional parts of `sktime` optional, not force users install packages they do not really need.

I don't think it is too relevant whether the combined forces of the four of you can fix @ngupta23's issue, since it is just a representative for interactions/restrictions that are caused by having more core dependencies.

> By making it a soft dependency we're implying it's a niche utility. It shouldn't be perceived this way but instead as one of sktimes developers best ways to optimise their code.

Don't think that is the implication at all.

I think it just implies that we are managing our interface points well, and minimize coupling where we can.
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39946/coupling-and-cohesion
(we can probably get to a point where `pandas` and `scikit-learn` are the only direct dependencies!)

> > Agreed. you would not be able to use around 50% (?) of all time series classification, regression, transformation packages without numba being installed.
> 
> Well, some users are not able to use 100% of all time series classification, regression, and transformation estimators because numba is installed, see above @ngupta23's comment.
> 
> We should strive to minimize dependencies and make optional parts of `sktime` optional, not force users install packages they do not really need.

Numba should be a must for the functionailty provided in sktime. It is the obvious way to get best performance. 

> I don't think it is too relevant whether the combined forces of the four of you can fix @ngupta23's issue, since it is just a representative for interactions/restrictions that are caused by having more core dependencies.

You should not fix a bug by removing 50% of a libraries functionality but by addressing the issue

> Whether numba is made a soft dependency or not, it is still an issue to resolve.

Can you add this to the sktime setup? We can retry after this is done to see if it resolves the issue?

https://github.com/numba/numba/issues/4908#issuecomment-571537473

```
Another workaround is to add zip_safe=False to the setup.py file of the packages that use numba caching.
```
